rules.natural: If a medical procedure requires pre-approval, then the insurance claim is reimbursed.
Whenever an insurance claim is approved, it is reimbursed.
If medical documentation is complete, then the insurance claim is processed.
Medical documentation is complete or incomplete.
In the event that medical documentation is incomplete, the insurance claim is approved.
An insurance claim being investigated implies that it is denied.
An insurance claim that is denied is not fraudulent.
The submission of an insurance claim leads to its approval.
Given that an insurance policy is valid, if the insurance claim is processed, it is submitted.
Either an appeal is filed for the insurance claim, or complete medical documentation results in the claim being approved.
A prescription drug requiring pre-approval entails that the insurance claim is reimbursed.
When an audit is triggered for an insurance claim, the claim is reviewed.
An insurance claim being escalated means that an appeal is not filed for it.
A routine medical procedure necessitates pre-approval.
A medical procedure is either routine or experimental.
If a medical procedure is covered by an insurance plan, then an experimental procedure implies that a prescription drug requires pre-approval.
Should a medical procedure not be covered by an insurance plan, then if it is experimental, a prescription drug requires pre-approval.
A medical procedure is in-network or out-of-network.
An out-of-network medical procedure is not covered by an insurance plan.
Either a medical procedure is an emergency, or an in-network procedure being covered by an insurance plan holds.
If it is not the case that complete medical documentation leads to approval of the insurance claim, then the claim is fraudulent.
Assuming that complete medical documentation does not result in approval of the insurance claim, the claim is investigated.
If it is not true that a reviewed insurance claim is escalated, then the claim has a minor discrepancy.
If it is not the case that the negation of "a reviewed insurance claim is escalated" implies no minor discrepancy, then the claim involves major fraud.

facts.natural: An audit is triggered for an insurance claim.
An insurance claim does not involve major fraud.
A medical procedure is not an emergency.

An insurance claim is reimbursed.
Should an insurance claim be investigated, it is not fraudulent.
In the event that complete medical documentation does not imply approval of the insurance claim, the claim is not fraudulent.
Provided that medical documentation is complete, the insurance claim is approved.
An insurance claim is approved.
An insurance claim is reimbursed.
Processing an insurance claim results in its submission.
Under the condition that medical documentation is complete, the insurance claim is submitted.
Provided that medical documentation is complete, the insurance claim is approved.
An insurance claim is approved.
An insurance claim is reimbursed.
Provided that a reviewed insurance claim is not escalated, the claim does not have a minor discrepancy.
Provided an insurance claim is reviewed, it is escalated.
In the case that an insurance claim is reviewed, an appeal is not filed for it.
If an audit is triggered for an insurance claim, then an appeal is not filed for it.
It is not the case that an appeal is filed for an insurance claim.
Provided that medical documentation is complete, the insurance claim is approved.
An insurance claim is approved.
An insurance claim is reimbursed.

(A1 → G).natural: If a medical procedure requires pre-approval, then the insurance claim is reimbursed.

(A1 ∨ A2).natural: Either a medical procedure requires pre-approval or a prescription drug requires pre-approval.

(A10 → G).natural: Whenever an insurance claim is approved, it is reimbursed.

(A11 → A10).natural: Provided that medical documentation is complete, the insurance claim is approved.

(A11 → A16).natural: Under the condition that medical documentation is complete, the insurance claim is submitted.

(A11 → A17).natural: If medical documentation is complete, then the insurance claim is processed.

(A11 ∨ A12).natural: Medical documentation is complete or incomplete.

(A12 → A10).natural: In the event that medical documentation is incomplete, the insurance claim is approved.

(A14 → A15).natural: An insurance claim being investigated implies that it is denied.

(A14 → ¬A13).natural: Should an insurance claim be investigated, it is not fraudulent.

(A15 → ¬A13).natural: An insurance claim that is denied is not fraudulent.

(A16 → A10).natural: The submission of an insurance claim leads to its approval.

(A17 → A16).natural: Processing an insurance claim results in its submission.

(A18 → (A17 → A16)).natural: Given that an insurance policy is valid, if the insurance claim is processed, it is submitted.

(A19 ∨ (A11 → A10)).natural: Either an appeal is filed for the insurance claim, or complete medical documentation results in the claim being approved.

(A2 → G).natural: A prescription drug requiring pre-approval entails that the insurance claim is reimbursed.

(A20 → A21).natural: When an audit is triggered for an insurance claim, the claim is reviewed.

(A20 → ¬A19).natural: If an audit is triggered for an insurance claim, then an appeal is not filed for it.

(A21 → A22).natural: Provided an insurance claim is reviewed, it is escalated.

(A21 → ¬A19).natural: In the case that an insurance claim is reviewed, an appeal is not filed for it.

(A22 → ¬A19).natural: An insurance claim being escalated means that an appeal is not filed for it.

(A3 → A1).natural: A routine medical procedure necessitates pre-approval.

(A3 ∨ A4).natural: A medical procedure is either routine or experimental.

(A4 → A2).natural: Whenever a medical procedure is experimental, a prescription drug requires pre-approval.

(A5 → (A4 → A2)).natural: If a medical procedure is covered by an insurance plan, then an experimental procedure implies that a prescription drug requires pre-approval.

(A5 ∨ A6).natural: A medical procedure is covered by an insurance plan or not covered by an insurance plan.

(A6 → (A4 → A2)).natural: Should a medical procedure not be covered by an insurance plan, then if it is experimental, a prescription drug requires pre-approval.

(A7 → A5).natural: An in-network medical procedure is covered by an insurance plan.

(A7 ∨ A8).natural: A medical procedure is in-network or out-of-network.

(A8 → A6).natural: An out-of-network medical procedure is not covered by an insurance plan.

(A9 ∨ (A7 → A5)).natural: Either a medical procedure is an emergency, or an in-network procedure being covered by an insurance plan holds.

(¬(A11 → A10) → A13).natural: If it is not the case that complete medical documentation leads to approval of the insurance claim, then the claim is fraudulent.

(¬(A11 → A10) → A14).natural: Assuming that complete medical documentation does not result in approval of the insurance claim, the claim is investigated.

(¬(A11 → A10) → ¬A13).natural: In the event that complete medical documentation does not imply approval of the insurance claim, the claim is not fraudulent.

(¬(A21 → A22) → A23).natural: If it is not true that a reviewed insurance claim is escalated, then the claim has a minor discrepancy.

(¬(A21 → A22) → ¬A23).natural: Provided that a reviewed insurance claim is not escalated, the claim does not have a minor discrepancy.

(¬(¬(A21 → A22) → ¬A23) → A24).natural: If it is not the case that the negation of "a reviewed insurance claim is escalated" implies no minor discrepancy, then the claim involves major fraud.

A20.natural: An audit is triggered for an insurance claim.

¬A19.natural: It is not the case that an appeal is filed for an insurance claim.

¬A24.natural: An insurance claim does not involve major fraud.

¬A9.natural: A medical procedure is not an emergency.
